awd_titl_txt: Transforming Undergraduate Learning to Enhance Innovation for a Changing World
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by developing a new model for designing and delivering innovation-focused undergraduate STEM education. Undergraduate education today is typically fractured into multiple different colleges and departments.  As a result, students often have limited opportunities to develop important skills, such as innovating in multidisciplinary teams, considering human elements in problem-solving, and transforming ideas into reliable investments of time and resources. To make such opportunities more available, this Level 1 Institutional and Community Transformation project aims to build a transdisciplinary, scalable model for innovation-focused undergraduate learning that crosses academic units and student majors. This model will include a student-centered, cross college/department community of practice to design and co-teach innovation-focused undergraduate courses.  A key feature of the project is collaboration among academic units to develop courses that include engineering/technology/design issues, the human and cultural interface of liberal arts/social sciences, and the economic perspectives of business management.  This context is expected to focus student learning on real problems in ways that span courses and course levels.  The project will simultaneously study institutional barriers to this change in undergraduate education. Taken as a whole, the project may yield insights and suggest next steps for other institutions that seek to engage in large-scale educational transformations. 

This project is designed to leverage strengths of Purdue University’s Polytechnic Institute, College of Liberal Arts, and Krannert School of Management to create leading-edge, innovation-focused undergraduate learning experiences. First, the project will implement a design-based research approach to create, test, and refine an educational model for transforming traditional siloed undergraduate learning experiences into experiences that span across disciplines and academic departments/individual courses. This model is expected to provide the institutional structure for achieving transformative undergraduate learning through the implementation of evidence-based practices.  Synergistically, the community of practice, which includes faculty, administrators, and community partners, is intended to provide an environment that will nourish student learning and support their innovative ideas. The project will use ethnographic methods to examine university change processes, identify best practices to guide institutional transformation, develop methods for co-teaching courses across units, and examine ways to reach larger audiences and sustain learning over time. The project centers on the hypothesis that a cross-college approach to transformation that focuses on expanding the practice of innovation across campus boundaries will better prepare next generation STEM innovators. The project also seeks to address the current need for rapid and profound changes in higher education, which makes conditions more favorable for institutional transformation. The data collected through this project will help provide a better understanding of the enablers and obstacles for different academic units to jointly develop new undergraduate educational models. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Institutional and Community Transformation track, the program supports efforts to transform and improve STEM education across institutions of higher education and disciplinary communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Universities face growing pressure to demonstrate their relevance in preparing undergraduates for today’s complex world. The Mission, Meaning, Making (M3) [Transforming Undergraduate Learning to Enhance Innovation for a Changing World] project was launched in response to this challenge, aiming to equip students with the mindsets and skills needed to become creative problem solvers who can address real-world challenges through innovation. By bringing together faculty and students from engineering/technology, liberal arts, and business, M3 tested new ways of teaching that cut across traditional academic silos and focused on authentic, student-driven design projects.

A central goal of M3 was to develop a transdisciplinary educational model engaging learners of multiple disciplinary backgrounds. This model is premised on the belief that innovation can flourish when people with varied expertise collaborate, share perspectives, and integrate insights to tackle pressing social and technological problems. The project team took a design-based research approach, iterating on course structures, assignments, and pedagogical methods over seven semesters. Faculty from different colleges co-taught classes in the same room at the same time, while students worked in teams that blended majors and interests. With the model now institutionalized in a cross-college Design & Innovation Minor, hundreds of undergraduates from over 65 different majors gained experience and credentials in combining business thinking, anthropological perspectives, and engineering techniques to develop impactful solutions.

To understand how universities can support this type of convergence education, the project also investigated institutional barriers and educational traditions. Through interviews, surveys, and ethnography, we identified factors that inhibit cross-college collaboration--such as rigid departmental structures, unit funding models, and complex curriculum approval processes. By sharing recommendations with administrators and faculty committees, M3 helped highlight the need for more flexible scheduling, revised ideas for supporting educational innovation, and streamlined processes for new joint course ventures. These insights extend beyond a single institution, providing guidance for other universities seeking to foster a more transdisciplinary approach to undergraduate education through disciplinary convergence.

Another major outcome was the creation of a residential learning community, where first-year students live together, learn about the shared practices of design and innovation, and connect with mentors to further explore their own creative interests. Over four cohorts, more than 260 students joined this community, participating in innovation challenges, skill-building workshops, and collaborative projects that connected them with resources across the entire campus. This living-learning environment helped cultivate a supportive peer network, reinforcing the idea that innovation is not just a classroom activity but also a mindset one carries into professional and personal life.

M3 also aimed to offer a broader pathway to innovation by establishing an early college pathway for high school students. Through a "facilitator model," high school teachers guide coursework developed by faculty, while official university instructors-of-record grade assignments and issue college credit. This approach has expanded access, particularly for students in urban and rural schools, enabling them to begin their design and innovation journeys before campus arrival. Over 150 high school students completed the introductory innovation course this way, discovering that innovation is not confined to advanced college labs but can thrive in any supportive learning environment.

For intellectual merit, the M3 project generated new knowledge on how to design truly transdisciplinary curricula. Its findings reveal that bringing together different disciplines in the same classroom sparks fresh thinking, motivates students to tackle socio-technical challenges, and encourages faculty to reimagine their teaching in more collaborative ways. This work also enriches the scholarship on "convergence education"--the melding of different fields to solve complex problems--and offers guidance on how to structure such experiences to maintain academic rigor while also nurturing creativity.

In terms of broader impacts, the project directly shaped the lives of participating students, some of whom used their M3 experiences to start small businesses, secure patents, or win grants and competitions. Accordingly, undergraduates who engaged in M3 courses have secured internal and external funds to advance their ideas in areas such as assistive technology, artificial intelligence, patient safety, and educational tools. High school students in the early college model gained early exposure to innovation-focused learning, broadening access to dual-credit opportunities and easing their transition into higher education. The project also employed/mentored graduate students as teaching assistants, research analysts, and co-designers of the curriculum. These graduate students went on to author theses and papers grounded in M3 data and continued to work in education.

By the award period's end, M3 evolved into a scalable and sustainable program, demonstrating that transdisciplinary innovation is possible within a large research institution. Although barriers like administrative turnover and departmental silos persist, the project's findings suggest concrete ways to align resources, incentives, and policies for lasting change. Looking ahead, the project results can help to enable convergence education practices--where disciplines merge to tackle real-world challenges--become a cornerstone of undergraduate learning.
